definition: to feel vexed/to bother/to trouble/superfluous and confusing/edgy

sentences.english: That's why I'm always in trouble alone.
sentences.chinese: 所以我才經常自尋煩惱。

sentences.english: I know she’s going to do it and so I don’t bother.
sentences.chinese: 我知道她會剪的，所以我就不必自尋煩惱了。

sentences.english: Don't be a worrywart. Everything's going to be fine.
sentences.chinese: 別自尋煩惱，一切都會變好的。

sentences.english: Actually your joyfulness presents itself to you. It is pity that most people never know when they are well.
sentences.chinese: 其實快樂就在眼前，可惜大多數人不知足，自尋煩惱。

sentences.english: Most businesses fail, why should I bother?
sentences.chinese: 多數創業都失敗了，我還要自尋煩惱幹嗎？

sentences.english: Sometimes, wishful thinking or self-assertion is in bring trouble on oneself.
sentences.chinese: 有時候啊，一廂情願或者自作多情都是在自尋煩惱。

sentences.english: It was not in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on them.
sentences.chinese: 以她那樣性格的人，也不會盡想着這些事自尋煩惱。

sentences.english: Fooling around with hard-earned savings is asking for trouble.
sentences.chinese: 有了點血汗錢就遊手好閒，那是自尋煩惱。

sentences.english: I don't want to get into trouble.
Tell him not to agitate himself.
We too often borrow trouble, and  anticipate that may never appear.
sentences.chinese: 我們常常過多地自尋煩惱，杞人憂天。

sentences.english: We do not need to look for trouble, standing on this mountain, that mountain to look high.
sentences.chinese: 我們用不着自尋煩惱，站在這山去望那山的高。

sentences.english: I will follow his father's advice, no longer asking for trouble.
sentences.chinese: 我將聽從父親的勸告，再也不自尋煩惱了。

definition: spilt water is difficult to retrieve (idiom)/it's no use crying over spilt milk/what's done is done and can't be reversed/the damage is done/once divorced, there's no reuniting
to let emotions affect one's decisions
lit. chickens flying and dogs jumping (idiom)/fig. in chaos/in disarray
lit. small belly, chicken's gut (idiom); narrow-minded/petty
to patch up one's lie (when inconsistencies appear)/to cover (for sb who has lied)
to refute/to demolish (an argument, theory etc)
flippant and insincere (piece of writing or speech)/glib-tongued/oily
lit. to gnaw a book/to study/to cram
